prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the story (the author) is in the wrong. The situation is about their husband setting up his office in the bedroom, which is causing disruptions because he's on conference calls. The author suggested the basement, but he prefers the bedroom for the view. Now, she's having to manage the kids, household chores, and her own work, but when he's in the bedroom, she can't do anything without disturbing him.

So, the key points here: The husband chose to work in the bedroom despite the alternative being available. The basement was suggested as a better option because it's quieter and wouldn't interfere with her. The author is working from home too and managing the household. The husband is on calls that require silence, but the bedroom being his office makes the whole top floor off-limits to her. She's not promising silence if he stays in the bedroom, while the basement option would have guaranteed no disturbances. The question is whether she's in the wrong for not keeping him undisturbed.

First, the husband's choice to set up in the bedroom is the root cause. He has a job that's 90% conference calls, so he needs silence. But he chose the bedroom over the basement, which would have minimized disruptions. The author is not at fault for not being able to control all variables in the bedroom situation. She's managing kids, housework, and her own work. It's reasonable for her to push back on setting up in the bedroom if it causes so much conflict. The husband is in a better position to relocate to the basement for the sake of harmony. The author's position seems justified because she's trying to balance her responsibilities and her own needs. The husband's preference for the view shouldn't override the practical needs of the household. So, the answer is probably B (No, she's not in the wrong).
